title: Statistical Advantages/Disadvantages in Prolonging Dog Life Study
question_text:
Suppose a large dog food company has a new prototype that is supposed to prolong the life of dogs.
The company randomly selects two groups of $100\text{ dogs}$ each: one group will be fed this new food for the duration of their entire lives; the other group will be fed the leading competitorâ€™s brand of dog food.
Variables such as exercise, location, and medical treatment are all controlled for. However, the company needs to decide whether to use only a specific breed of dog or include a variety of dogs.
What is a statistical advantage of using only one specific breed of dog for this study? A statistical disadvantage?

choices.text:
Advantage: less variability in results
Disadvantage: difficult to generalize the results to other breeds

Advantage: less expensive to run the experiment
Disadvantage: difficult to generalize the results to other breeds

Advantage: more detailed information
Disadvantage: more lurking variables

Advantage: less variability in results
Disadvantage: difficult to obtain dogs of all the same breed

Advantage: less expensive to run the experiment
Disadvantage: more lurking variables

solution:
An advantage to using just one breed of dog in this experiment is that there will be less variability in results. Some breeds live longer than others, so by choosing a single breed, any variability in results can be attributed to the dog food and not other factors.

A disadvantage is that it could be difficult or unwise to generalize any results to other breeds of dogs. For instance, perhaps this food would work well for a certain breed but not for all breeds.

Note: Certain advantages and disadvantages listed in Choices 'B' through 'E' may seem reasonable, but they are not statistical advantages or disadvantages.
